Dimensions and Details ‚Ä¢ Height: Standing an impressive 12 meters (39 feet) tall, this bronze sculpture towers over its surroundings, making it one of the most striking landmarks in the area. ‚Ä¢ Weight: Approximately 18 tons, making it a marvel of engineering and artistic expression. ‚Ä¢ Creator: C√©sar Baldaccini, one of France‚Äôs most celebrated sculptors, created this work as part of his famous Empreintes (Imprints) series in the 1960s. The series focuses on enlarging everyday objects to monumental proportions, celebrating their simplicity and uniqueness. Caesar's Thumb is a bronze statue of the Italian sculptor C√©sar Baldaccini (1921-1998), famous for his humorous work.

Le Pouce is a play by Caesar. It is one of the works of art preserved in La D√©fense, France, an example of the series of works of the same name. The work is located next to the CNIT. It represents the author's enlarged thumb (1.85 m tall). In this regard he invokes his "narcissism" and the convenience offered by the immediate availability of the model. In 1965, the Claude-Bernard gallery in Paris commissioned a work from C√©sar for the exhibition ‚ÄúRodin's hand to Picasso‚Äù. The sculptor, having discovered the principle of pantographic enlargement, made the impression of his thumb using a molding which he enlarged up to 40 cm, but having few means at his disposal at the time, it was made of translucent pink plastic. Faced with the success of the work with its evident phallic symbolism, he decided to duplicate it in different sizes and materials. La D√©fense ordered one from him in 1989. The Thumb was inaugurated on the square in front of la D√©fense in 1994. In 2015, the statue was restored to its original appearance.

Caesar's Thumb, a monumental bronze sculpture installed in La D√©fense, is one of the most emblematic works of the artist C√©sar Baldaccini. Measuring almost 12 meters high, this work surprises with its size and its realism, representing a gigantic thumb which challenges and fascinates passers-by. A symbol of industrialization and the artist's hand at work, it arouses as much admiration as it raises questions, some seeing it as a technical feat, others as an offbeat curiosity. In any case, it remains an essential landmark in the modern urban landscape of Paris.

This work represents the thumb of the author (the artist Cesar) enlarged. In this regard, he invokes his ‚Äúnarcissism‚Äù and the convenience offered by the immediate availability of the model.  There are several reproductions of this sculpture, but the example located at La D√©fense, 12 m high and 18 tons heavy, is the most massive.

1965, Cezar, previously worked on metal, decided to use innovative materials, such as plastic or resin. He also began a series of works he called "Extensions" (as opposed to the Compressions he did previously), based on the principle of pantograph expansion. On this date, Paris gallery owner Claude-Bernard in Paris commissioned a work from C√©sar for the exhibition "Rodin's Hand to Picasso"
